title: Uniformly most powerful test
text:
In <a href="statistical%20hypothesis%20testing">statistical hypothesis testing</a>, a uniformly most powerful (UMP) test is a <a href="statistical%20hypothesis%20testing">hypothesis test</a> which has the greatest <a href="Statistical%20power">power</a> formula_1 among all possible tests of a given <a href="Type%20I%20and%20type%20II%20errors">size</a> "α". For example, according to the <a href="Neyman%E2%80%93Pearson%20lemma">Neyman–Pearson lemma</a>, the <a href="likelihood-ratio%20test">likelihood-ratio</a> test is UMP for testing simple (point) hypotheses.

Further discussion.
Finally, we note that in general, UMP tests do not exist for vector parameters or for two-sided tests (a test in which one hypothesis lies on both sides of the alternative). The reason is that in these situations, the most powerful test of a given size for one possible value of the parameter (e.g. for formula_49 where formula_50) is different from the most powerful test of the same size for a different value of the parameter (e.g. for formula_51 where formula_52). As a result, no test is uniformly most powerful in these situations.
